questions.text: All of the following is seen in Acute Nephritic syndrome except?
questions.solution:
• Acute Nephritic Syndrome is associated with:
    • Haematuria with RBC casts, indicating glomerular damage.
    • Proteinuria: Typically mild (1-2 g/day), reflecting mild glomerular leakage.
    • Hypertension, due to fluid retention and impaired kidney function.
    • Rising serum creatinine, reflecting reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
  • >3.0 grams/day proteinuria is excessive for nephritic syndrome and is a hallmark of nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome also features hypoalbuminemia and severe edema.

Why Not Others:

  • B. Haematuria with RBC casts: Typical in nephritic syndrome due to glomerular inflammation.
  • C. Rise in serum creatinine: Seen in nephritic syndrome due to decreased GFR.
  • D. Hypertension: Common in nephritic syndrome due to fluid overload and renal dysfunction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Nephritic Syndrome: Mild proteinuria (<3 g/day), haematuria, hypertension, and rising creatinine.
  • Nephrotic Syndrome: Marked by >3 g/day proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and significant edema.

questions.text: A young female with malar rash and low grade fever presents with new onset Pedal oedema. Evaluation shows hypertension, increased urea and creatinine with 24 hour urine protein 1.5 gram with active urine sediments. ANA is high titer positive. Renal biopsy is reported as proliferative lupus nephritis. Which of the following class of lesions in Lupus Nephritis are considered as proliferative?
questions.solution:
• Class III and IV lupus nephritis are proliferative lesions, meaning they cause active inflammation of the glomeruli.
  • Class III (Focal) affects <50% of glomeruli, while Class IV (Diffuse) affects >50% of glomeruli, leading to more severe kidney involvement.
  • Class V is membranous, typically causing nephrotic syndrome without significant inflammation, unless mixed with proliferative classes like III or IV.
  • Nephritic syndrome, characterized by hematuria, RBC casts, and proteinuria, is usually seen in Class III and IV.
  • Anti-dsDNA antibodies are key markers correlating with renal disease in lupus.

Why not others:

  • Option B: Class V is not proliferative unless mixed with III or IV.
  • Option C: Class II is mesangial, which is non-proliferative and typically less severe.
  • Option D: Class III alone does not cover the full spectrum of proliferative lesions, as Class IV is also included.

Key takeaways:

  • Class III (Focal) and Class IV (Diffuse) are the main proliferative lupus nephritis
  • Class V is membranous and non-proliferative unless mixed with III or IV, and Anti-dsDNA antibodies correlate with renal involvement in lupus nephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
• Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis primarily occurs after skin or throat infections caused by nephritogenic strains of streptococci.
  • Antibiotic therapy does not reduce the risk of nephritis; it only helps to eliminate the active infection.
  • Immunosuppressive therapy is not indicated, even in the presence of crescents on biopsy.
  • Prognosis is typically better in children than in the elderly.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Antibiotics do not prevent the development of nephritis.
  • Option B: Immunosuppressants are not used, even with crescents.
  • Option C: Prognosis is better in children compared to the elderly.

Key Takeaways:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is immune-mediated and typically follows streptococcal infections.
  • Antibiotics treat the infection, but they don’t prevent nephritis; immunosuppressants are not indicated.
  • Prognosis is worse in the elderly.

questions.text: An young male presents with haemoptysis and pedal oedema. For rapidly progressive respiratory distress he is admitted to ICU. On evaluation diagnosis of anti-GBM disease is made. Which of the following is target antigen for anti-GBM disease?
questions.solution:
• Anti-GBM Disease: Characterized by the presence of antibodies against the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV. This autoimmune disease affects both the kidneys and lungs, leading to a condition known as Goodpasture's syndrome.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients often exhibit haemoptysis (coughing up blood) and pulmonary-renal syndrome, presenting with both lung hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis.
  • Pathophysiology: The target epitopes in collagen IV are typically hidden but can be exposed by factors like infection, smoking, or oxidative stress. This triggers the immune response leading to tissue damage.
  • Biopsy Findings: Renal biopsy in suspected cases reveals focal or segmental necrosis and can show crescent formation in Bowman’s space due to severe damage to the glomerular capillaries. Linear immunofluorescent staining for IgG confirms the presence of anti-GBM antibodies.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Α5 NC1 domain of collagen III: Incorrect, as this is not the target antigen in anti-GBM disease.
  • C. Alpha5 NC1 domain of collagen IV: Also incorrect; the correct domain is α3 NC1.
  • D. α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV: Repeated option; both D and C are incorrect as presented.

Key Takeaways:

  • Anti-GBM disease targets the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV, leading to Goodpasture's syndrome with pulmonary and renal manifestations.
  • Urgent kidney biopsy is crucial for diagnosis; plasma exchange therapy is often effective for treatment.
  • Poor prognosis correlates with significant crescent formation and elevated serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: A 18 years old male presents with purpuric skin rash, macroscopic haematuria and colicky pain abdomen 1 week after episode of sore throat Renal biopsy shows dominant mesangial IgA deposits, either alone or with IgG, IgM, or C3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with:
    • Purpuric skin rash: Indicates systemic involvement.
    • Macroscopic hematuria: Suggestive of renal involvement.
    • Colicky abdominal pain: Commonly seen in IgA vasculitis.
    • Symptoms appear 1 week after sore throat, indicating a possible preceding infection.
  • Renal biopsy findings:
    • Dominant mesangial IgA deposits: Pathognomonic for IgA vasculitis, often seen alone or with IgG, IgM, or C3.
  • Differentiating factors:
    • Age of Presentation:
      • IgA vasculitis: Commonly occurs in <20 years.
      • IgA nephropathy: More frequent in the 2nd and 3rd decades of life.
    • Systemic Symptoms:
      • IgA vasculitis: Associated with systemic symptoms like purpura and abdominal pain.
      • IgA nephropathy: Typically lacks systemic symptoms.
    • Preceding Infection:
      • IgA vasculitis: Often follows a respiratory infection.
      • IgA nephropathy: Preceding infections are less common.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A (Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis):
    • Associated with recent streptococcal infections, not fitting the presented symptoms and biopsy findings.
  • Option B (IgA Nephropathy):
    • Involves IgA deposits but lacks the systemic symptoms and typical age profile presented.
  • Option D (Unable to say based on the data given):
    • Sufficient information is available to make a clear diagnosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Most likely diagnosis is IgA vasculitis due to the systemic symptoms and age.
  • Differentiation from IgA nephropathy is based on presentation and systemic involvement.
  • Kidney biopsy findings support the diagnosis of IgA vasculitis, especially with mesangial IgA deposits.

questions.text: Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules are histopathological finding in which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
• Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules are pathognomonic for Diabetic Nephropathy.
  • They are characterized as eosinophilic, PAS+ nodules associated with nodular glomerulosclerosis.
  • Thickening of the GBM (glomerular basement membrane) is a sensitive indicator of diabetes but correlates poorly with nephropathy presence.
  • Expansion of mesangial matrix occurs due to sustained glomerular hypertension, increasing matrix production and disrupting the filtration barrier.
  • Advanced glycosylation end products and circulating factors (e.g., TGF-β, growth hormones) further alter matrix production.
  • Microalbuminuria (30–300 mg/24 h) appears 5–10 years post-diabetes onset; testing for it is recommended annually in at-risk populations.
  • Retinopathy presence is significant in diagnosing diabetic nephropathy; its absence in type 1 patients with proteinuria suggests alternative diagnoses.
  • There is a strong correlation between retinopathy and Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules, indicating a severe disease state.
  • Management includes stringent control of blood sugar and blood pressure, with RAAS inhibitors and SGLT2 inhibitors showing clear benefits in slowing progression.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: IgA nephropathy - Involves mesangial IgA deposits but does not feature Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules.
  • Option C: Idiopathic membranous Glomerulonephritis - Characterized by diffuse capillary thickening, not Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules.
  • Option D: Wilson disease - Primarily associated with copper accumulation and liver dysfunction, not related to Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules.

Key Takeaways:

  • Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules are specific to Diabetic Nephropathy, indicating nodular glomerulosclerosis.
  • Proper diagnosis and management of diabetic patients, including screening for microalbuminuria, is crucial for preventing kidney complications.
  • Controlling blood sugar and blood pressure is essential to mitigate the progression of diabetic nephropathy and associated complications.

questions.text: Combination of Haematuria, sub nephrotic proteinuria, sensorineural hearing loss and dot and fleck retinopathy is seen in which of the following clinical condition?
questions.solution:
• Alport syndrome is characterized by a classic triad of haematuria, sub-nephrotic proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Patients often present with thinning and splitting of the GBMs (glomerular basement membranes) and mild proteinuria, typically appearing later in the disease course.
  • Chronic glomerulosclerosis may develop, leading to renal failure over time.
  • Dot and fleck retinopathy and lenticonus of the anterior lens capsule are additional ocular findings associated with Alport syndrome.
  • The condition predominantly has X-linked inheritance, affecting approximately 85% of patients due to mutations in the α5(IV) collagen chain on chromosome Xq22-24.
  • Autosomal recessive forms involve mutations in the α3(IV) or α4(IV) chains on chromosome 2q35-37, and rare cases of autosomal dominant inheritance have also been noted.
  • Poor prognostic factors include early severe deafness, lenticonus, or significant proteinuria.
  • Diagnosis may be supported by skin biopsies revealing a lack of the α5(IV) collagen chain via immunofluorescence; renal biopsy may be needed for other mutations.
  • Management focuses on controlling systemic hypertension and using ACE inhibitors to slow renal progression.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Fabry disease - Characterized by lysosomal storage disorder, presenting with different renal and systemic findings, such as angiokeratomas and acroparesthesias, rather than the classic symptoms of Alport syndrome.
  • Option B: Fibrillary glomerulopathy - Presents with nephrotic syndrome and non-specific findings, lacking the characteristic retinopathy and hearing loss associated with Alport syndrome.
  • Option C: Renal amyloidosis - Characterized by proteinuria and possibly haematuria, but does not involve the specific symptoms of hearing loss or retinopathy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder with a classic presentation of haematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss, often associated with dot and fleck retinopathy.
  • Early diagnosis and management, including hypertension control and ACE inhibitors, are crucial for improving patient outcomes and slowing disease progression.

questions.text: A 18 years old male presents with fever and drowsiness for 2 days and is admitted for work up. Investigation reveals Severe anaemia with corrected reticulocyte count of 4% and presence of schistocytes in peripheral blood. Urea and creatinine is raised. Infection work up in CSF is normal. serum electrolytes and blood sugar are normal. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is characterized by:
    • Severe anemia with schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells) present in the peripheral blood.
    • Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), although not explicitly mentioned here, is a common feature.
    • Renal impairment, indicated by raised urea and creatinine levels.
    • Neurological symptoms, as suggested by drowsiness.
    • The presence of fever can also be associated with the condition.
  • TTP is part of a spectrum of thrombotic microangiopathies (TMAs), which include:
    • Shiga toxin–mediated hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) and complement-mediated HUS.
    • Common features include idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, hemolytic anemia, renal failure, and neurologic disturbances.
  • In TTP, a deficiency of the ADAMTS13 metalloprotease leads to accumulation of large von Willebrand factor multimers, resulting in platelet clumping and intravascular hemolysis. The presence of antibodies to ADAMTS13 is common in many cases.
  • Management includes:
    • Plasmapheresis as a lifesaving treatment to remove antibodies and replenish ADAMTS13.
    • Fresh frozen plasma may also be used until platelet counts improve.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Herpes encephalitis - Typically presents with fever, altered mental status, and seizures but not with hemolytic anemia or schistocytes.
  • Option C: Antiphospholipid syndrome - May cause thrombosis and is associated with pregnancy complications but does not typically present with hemolytic anemia or schistocytes.
  • Option D: HELLP syndrome - Associated with severe pregnancy complications (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelets) but less likely in an 18-year-old male without pregnancy history.

Key Takeaways:

  • TTP presents with severe anemia, schistocytes, and renal impairment alongside fever and neurological symptoms.
  • Early recognition and treatment with plasmapheresis are crucial for improving patient outcomes in TTP.

questions.text: Tram Tracking of basement membrane is seen in which of the following glomerulopathy?
questions.solution:
• Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is characterized by:
    • Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) along with mesangioproliferative changes.
    • A lobular appearance of the glomerular tuft due to mesangial proliferation.
    • Tram tracking refers to the double contour appearance of the GBM, caused by mesangial interposition between the capillary basement membrane and endothelial cells.
  • Types of MPGN:
    • Type I MPGN:
      • Immune complex-mediated, associated with hepatitis B and C, autoimmune diseases, and monoclonal gammopathies (e.g., monoclonal gammopathy of renal significance).
      • It shows pronounced mesangial proliferation and lobular segmentation.
    • Types II and III MPGN:
      • Non-immunoglobulin-mediated, driven by the alternate complement pathway.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Can manifest as either nephrotic or nephritic syndrome.
  • Management:
    • Inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system are beneficial.
    • Eculizumab may be indicated if defects in the complement pathway are identified.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Mesangioproliferative GN - While it involves mesangial proliferation, it does not specifically exhibit tram tracking of the GBM.
  • Option B: Minimal change disease - Primarily characterized by podocyte effacement without changes in the GBM structure.
  • Option D: IgA nephropathy - Typically presents with IgA deposition and hematuria, without the tram tracking phenomenon.

Key Takeaways:

  • MPGN is marked by tram tracking of the basement membrane, indicating significant structural changes in the glomeruli.
  • Understanding MPGN types and their associations is crucial for effective diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following forms of Glomerulopathy is seen in remaining kidney after nephrectomy?
questions.solution:
• Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by:
    • Segmental glomerular scars that affect some but not all glomeruli.
    • It commonly occurs in patients with a single remaining kidney following nephrectomy, as compensatory hyperfiltration may lead to glomerulosclerosis in the surviving nephron.
  • Genetic Factors:
    • Risk polymorphisms at the APOL1 locus in podocytes are significantly associated with an increased prevalence of FSGS, especially among African Americans.
  • Pathology:
    • Pathologic changes are often most noticeable in glomeruli near the corticomedullary junction; superficial biopsy samples may miss lesions, leading to misdiagnosis.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • FSGS can manifest with:
      • Hematuria
      • Hypertension
      • Variable levels of proteinuria
      • Renal insufficiency
    • Patients with nephrotic-range proteinuria, particularly of African American descent, are at higher risk for poor outcomes, with a significant chance of progressing to renal failure within 6–8 years.
  • Management:
    • The treatment plan includes:
      • Inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system.
      • Steroids may be beneficial for primary FSGS with nephrotic-range proteinuria, but responses are generally less favorable compared to Minimal Change Disease (MCD).
      • There is no role for steroids or immunosuppressive agents in secondary FSGS.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Membranous - Typically does not specifically occur in the remaining kidney after nephrectomy.
  • Option C: Minimal change disease - More common in children and not specifically linked to nephrectomy.
  • Option D: Mesangioproliferative - While it can occur post-nephrectomy, it is not the typical finding.

Key Takeaways:

  • FSGS is the primary glomerulopathy seen in the remaining kidney after nephrectomy, often due to compensatory mechanisms.
  • Genetic factors play a significant role in the predisposition to FSGS, particularly in certain ethnic groups.

questions.text: 35 years old male presents with nephrotic range proteinuria. On evaluation antibody against phospholipase A2 is present. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Idiopathic Membranous Glomerulonephritis (MGN) is characterized by:
    • Nephrotic syndrome with significant proteinuria.
    • The presence of antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R), which occurs in approximately 70% of idiopathic cases.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Accounts for about 25% of nephrotic syndrome cases in adults.
    • Peak incidence occurs between 30 and 50 years, with a male-to-female ratio of 2:1.
  • Pathology:
    • Renal biopsy typically shows:
      • Uniform thickening of the basement membrane along peripheral capillary loops.
      • Immunofluorescence reveals granular deposits of IgG and C3.
      • Electron microscopy displays electron-dense subepithelial deposits.
    • Differentiation:
      • Subendothelial deposits or tubuloreticular inclusions indicate membranous lupus nephritis.
      • The presence of autoantibodies to thrombospondin type-1 domain-containing 7A (THSD7A) is noted in 3-10% of cases.
    • Prognosis:
      • Factors such as male gender, older age, hypertension, and persistent nephrotic-range proteinuria are associated with a poorer prognosis.
      • MGN has a higher incidence of thrombotic complications like renal vein thrombosis, prompting consideration for prophylactic anticoagulation in patients with hypoalbuminemia.

Why Not Others:

  • Option B: Secondary membranous Glomerulonephritis - This involves other underlying conditions, which is not indicated here.
  • Option C: SLE associated membranous GN - Would show additional features of systemic lupus erythematosus, which are not present in this case.
  • Option D: Drug-induced Membranous Glomerulonephritis - Requires a known drug history, which is absent here.

Key Takeaways:

  • Idiopathic Membranous Glomerulonephritis is confirmed with the presence of PLA2R antibodies and significant nephrotic range proteinuria.
  • Pathological features include thickened membranes and characteristic subepithelial deposits, crucial for diagnosis and differentiation from other forms.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for initial therapy in minimal change disease in adults is?
questions.solution:
• Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is characterized by:
    • Prevalence: Accounts for 70-90% of nephrotic syndrome in children but only 10-15% in adults.
    • Clinical Presentation: Abrupt onset of edema and nephrotic syndrome with acellular urinary sediment.
  • Pathological Findings:
    • Renal Biopsy: Typically shows no lesions by light microscopy and lacks deposits on immunofluorescent microscopy.
    • Electron Microscopy: Reveals effacement of foot processes of podocytes, which is a hallmark of MCD.
  • Treatment:
    • Initial Therapy: Glucocorticoids alone are the first-line treatment.
      • Adults usually achieve complete remission after 20-24 weeks of therapy.
      • Up to 80-85% of adults may achieve complete remission with appropriate steroid therapy.
    • Other immunosuppressants (e.g., cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate) are reserved for patients with frequent relapses, steroid dependency, or steroid resistance.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Cyclosporine + glucocorticoids - Not first-line; used for frequent relapses.
  • Option B: Cyclophosphamide + glucocorticoids - More aggressive; typically not initial treatment.
  • Option C: Mycophenolate + glucocorticoids - Also reserved for specific cases, not initial therapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Glucocorticoids alone are the primary treatment for Minimal Change Disease in adults, leading to significant remission rates.
  • Proper management and monitoring are essential, as adults may require a longer treatment duration to achieve remission compared to children.

questions.text: An elderly nondiabetic Nonhypertensive man with history of bone pain comes for evaluation. Evaluation shows raised serum creatinine, nephrotic range proteinuria, hypercalcemia and haemoglobin of 9.2 gm/dL. He undergoes renal biopsy. Which of the following special stains of renal biopsy is must in this case?
questions.solution:
• Clinical Presentation: Elderly male with:
    • CRAB symptoms: Calcium elevation (hypercalcemia), Renal dysfunction (raised serum creatinine), Anemia (hemoglobin 9.2 gm/dL), and Bone pain.
    • High suspicion for multiple myeloma or primary amyloidosis.
  • Importance of Staining:
    • Congo Red Stain: Essential for diagnosing amyloidosis.
      • Amyloidosis can lead to renal complications and is commonly associated with multiple myeloma.
      • Detects amyloid deposits in the kidney, appearing apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

Must-Know Facts about Renal Amyloidosis:

  • Types:
    • Primary (AL) amyloidosis: Resulting from immunoglobulin light chains.
    • Secondary (AA) amyloidosis: Due to serum amyloid A protein from chronic inflammation.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Renal amyloidosis leads to heavy proteinuria, nephrotic syndrome, and can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy, hepatomegaly, and macroglossia.
    • About 10% of patients may have overt myeloma with CRAB features.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum-free light chain analysis aids in diagnosis and monitoring.
    • Biopsy is definitive for amyloid deposits.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Masson Trichome - Used for fibrosis; not specific for amyloidosis.
  • Option B: Jones Methenamine - Used for identifying fungal elements and basement membrane; not relevant in this context.
  • Option D: Hematoxylin and eosin - Standard stain but does not detect amyloid deposits.

Key Takeaways:

  • Congo red staining is essential in renal biopsies for diagnosing amyloidosis, especially in patients with hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and bone pain.
  • Early recognition of amyloidosis can significantly influence management, particularly in the context of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: Zebra bodies on electron Microscopy of renal biopsy is a feature of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
• Key Finding: Zebra bodies on electron microscopy are characteristic of Fabry disease, which are electron-dense materials found in parallel arrays.

Must-Know Facts about Fabry Disease:

  • Genetics:
    • X-linked disorder due to deficiency in lysosomal α-galactosidase A
    • Leads to excessive accumulation of globotriaosylceramide.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Typically presents in childhood with symptoms such as:
      • Acroparesthesias (pain or discomfort in hands/feet)
      • Angiokeratomas (small, reddish-purple spots)
      • Cornea verticillata (corneal deposits)
      • Hypohidrosis (decreased sweating).
    • As patients age, complications include cardiomyopathy, cerebrovascular disease, and renal injury.
  • Renal Findings:
    • Renal biopsy shows:
      • Enlarged glomerular visceral epithelial cells filled with clear vacuoles (containing globotriaosylceramide).
      • Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) pattern observed in advanced cases.
    • Urinalysis may show oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules (Maltese cross appearance).
  • Diagnosis:
    • Measured by α-gal A activity and mutational analysis of the gene.
    • Renal biopsies can assist in diagnosis.
  • Management:
    • Recommended to use inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system.
    • Recombinant α-gal A or migalastat (chaperone therapy) can reduce globotriaosylceramide deposits in tissues.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Light chain deposition disease - Characterized by light chain deposits, not zebra bodies.
  • Option B: Anti-GBM disease - Involves antibodies against glomerular basement membrane; does not present with zebra bodies.
  • Option C: Nail patella syndrome - Associated with skeletal abnormalities, not related to zebra bodies in renal biopsy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Zebra bodies are a distinctive feature of Fabry disease in renal biopsies, indicating lysosomal storage disorder.
  • Early recognition and management can help mitigate complications associated with this X-linked condition, particularly renal failure and other systemic effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of Pulmonary-Renal Syndrome?
questions.solution:
• IgA nephropathy does not typically cause pulmonary involvement, distinguishing it from other causes of pulmonary-renal syndrome.
  • Common Causes:
    • Goodpasture’s syndrome: Autoimmune disorder causing anti-GBM antibodies leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage.
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis: A type of vasculitis that can cause both renal and pulmonary symptoms.
    • Cryoglobulinemia: Associated with systemic diseases, can lead to vasculitis affecting both kidneys and lungs.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms include hemoptysis (coughing up blood), renal failure, and respiratory distress.
    • Diagnosis can be challenging due to the overlap of symptoms; requires a combination of clinical, serologic, and histopathologic assessments.
  • Management:
    • Immediate treatment often includes plasmapheresis and methylprednisolone.
    • Dialysis may be required for acute renal failure.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis - Causes both pulmonary and renal involvement.
  • Option C: Cryoglobulinemia - Can lead to pulmonary-renal syndrome due to its effects on vasculature.
  • Option D: Goodpasture syndrome - Specifically causes both glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage.

Key Takeaways:

  • IgA nephropathy is primarily a renal condition and does not involve the lungs, unlike other listed conditions that are part of pulmonary-renal syndrome.
